Review:
Nashoda Rose is one of the very few authors that has not once disappointed me. Her books tend to skate the thin line of dark yet the love story within the plot seems to lighten the load.  Perfect Rage is Connor's story and with the tragic backstory of this character, I couldn't wait to see how she'd pull off such a painfully flawed character, that despite being a true hero, was held captive, drugged and turned until a cold-hearted anti-hero. Should I love him or hate him for the things he did to our beloved characters in Perfect Ruin?  I knew somehow this author would bring him back in my good graces but his road to recovery would be long and hard fought.

We've followed Connor O'Neill through all the Unyielding series books. Brother to Georgie in Perfect Chaos, army hero until he was captured by a Columbian drug lord and used for an experimental drug to take good men and make them into cold hearted killers.  Does he have a chance for mental rehabilitation after doing such horrible things? Can he live with himself and the long-term side effects of the drug he was given in captivity? Is there a chance for second chances with the deal changer for him all those years ago in the army, a woman named Catalina?

Perfect Rage was not an easy second-chance romance. Nashoda Rose did not go easy on Connor and his road to recovery and my heart broke for the man he'd become. The broken man that had so much taken away, had done so much under the influence of the drug. Regret. Guilt. Rage so deep within, it was palpable- like a brewing storm just waiting to erupt. I wanted to reach into my little kindle and hug the pain, the headaches, away from him.

Previously meeting Catalina Moreno in Perfect Ruin, I didn't form much of an opinion of her until reading this book- her story.  She too is a victim of the drug-lord Carlos Moreno yet she chose to fight to get her life back, fought tooth and nail to get her lover back she lost so many years ago. But is Connor the man she met and fell for over a decade ago or is he long gone, a victim of Vault and all their doings?

Nashoda Rose added so much to this book beyond just the Connor/Alina story. We got to see quite a bit of Deck/Georgie and Kai/London- the Unyielding crew. It's a battle well fought and I genuinely worried how she would pull off his rehabilitation and make it realistic but she did! Now I'd like to place an order for a certain man-whore character named Deaglan!

Review:
The Dragons Heart (Lochguard Highland Dragons Book# 3)

Jessie Donovan

An older female dragon and older human malethey have both loved before and lost. Can they find true love a 2nd Time around? Well

Lorna MacKenzie lost her true mate Jamie MacKenzie over 30yrs ago. She is NOT looking for love in any place at all! Ross Anderson had loved Anne deeply but she was taken from him tragically over a decade ago, then cancer struck. Ross had come to Lochguard with daughter Holly to save his life when she became a Sacrifice. Now Ross is Cancer Free, Holly is happily mated to Fraser, WHAT IS A BLOKE TO DO?!?!?!?!?!?

The book opens with Lorna in a quandary. Shes got a full life helping her family and extended family. An Old Flame has come out of the blue and throws her a look asking remember ME? Ross meantime has been secretly looking at Lorna, with something other than friendship in mind.  Oh, don't forget the Twins, Fergus and Fraser are very protective of their Mum. They do not like this LOOK Ross is giving Lorna, unh uh. Add in daughter Faye, shes a Trained Lochguard Protector, and very close to Mum as well you can see the twists and turns even before Jessie Mentions ANYTHING!

This is a delightful look at love a second time around through the eyes of a couple of grandparents. But don't put them in their dotage JUST yet! Neither has lost anything, both still really in their prime. They could run rings around many of us! Even thought they might not be 30 anymore, they don't let life stop them or get them down. So pull up a chair, get yourself a drink, and settle in with The Dragons Heart! I hope you chuckle as much as I did!

Review:
I'm not sure what to say about this.  It is an iPod dock that can be powered by a VERY large power brick, or 8xAA batteries.  It has a smalish remote which allows you to make selections on the iPod, pause/play, next/prev track, mute, vol up/down, bass boost and ROTATE.  The round grey button for Menu/up/down/ok needs to be pushed quite hard.  The center of the circle does nothing.  It is not a button.  Strange.  Why not make that "OK"?  Probably would infringe on an Apple patent or something.

The Rotate feature is why you would buy this instead of the litany of other iPod docks.  Push a button on the remote and the iPod turns 90 degrees counter-clockwise so you can watch a video in widescreen (if you have one of those iPods.)  This is kind of a cool gimmicky feature.  A button on the top turns off a backlight (the blue ring).  When on, the blue ring changes color when you rotate (to a lighter blue).

The sound quality on this is its largest flaw.  In a word, terrible.  You don't need to be much of a critic to know the sound is poor.  It reminds me of a transistor radio speaker from the 80s.  I'm pretty sure I can hear stereo sound.

The iPod connector also charges your iPod and there is a mini-plug in the back for a line-in (if you aren't using an actual ipod.)

It comes with a bunch of filler plates so all manner of iPods (with a standard iPod connector) will fit in the rotating mechanism.

I want to give it four stars, but the sound quality is so bad and the power brick is so large I can only justify three.  Oh, I almost forgot, you cannot use any type of iPod case with this thing - not even a super thin silicone case.  That settles it.  Three stars.

Review: OK, I almost gave this 2 stars because I couldn't unplug it from my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 (7-Inch, Wi-Fi). I finally got it off, so I plugged it in again and it stuck. Grr. Turns out that you need to pinch the sides to pull it out. Ahh - OK, it's earned some stars back. I'm still annoyed about the plug though - there wasn't anything on the packaging to say you had to pinch it. I have checked twice. (Please don't comment to say that it's not fair I'm docking it a star just because I'm stupid. Technically this should be idiot proof, and I've proven it's not.) OK, now that I'm breathing normally again, on to the review. At 4 feet, the cord is a foot longer than the one that came with the tab. Yay! The wall plug has folding blades that also twist so you can get them into most outlets. Review: Just as the Holy Bible reflects the mentality of society during the Bronze Age in which it was written, so likewise, does The 50 Funniest American Writers reflect the American Century, and I think that this book should replace the Bible as a source of comfort and inspiration to us all. And just as every home always had at least one Bible handy, even if no one there could read, everyone should have at least one copy of this book -- even if you can't read. Just as there were once squabbles over what Scripture should be included in the Bible (I'm partial to 2 Machabees and don't think it's been given a fair shake), one could argue that George Ade should instead be represented here by "The Joys of Single Blessedness" or "The Waist-Band That Was Taut Up To The Moment It Gave Way," or that H. L. Mencken's recollection of press agent "A. Toxen Worm" (whom he claimed was a real person) would've been the better choice. The 50 Funniest is analogous to The New American Standard Bible or even the Book of Mormon, as it includes recent selections, which is nice, because you can now read those pieces you once skipped over in The New Yawkeh. Although, if you have been keeping up with the weekly Shouts & Murmurs, and if you already have The Onion bookmarked, or if you are more interested in writers of the past, there are better collections than this. A Sub-Treasury of American Humor by Mr. & Mrs. E. B. White is better because it's a thicker book, and so is The Best of Modern Humor edited by Mordecai Richler. However, this collection by Borowitz has two things to recommend it over those volumes. One, you owe it to Andy to buy it, because he's been sending you The Borowitz Report for free (guilt!), and two, it's so cheap! That's another similarity with the Bible, because you can always steal a Bible from any hotel or motel room. Can't get any cheaper than that! I've obtained dozens in this manner, and one is propping-up a corner of my washing machine against the sloping basement floor. You apostates may scoff if you wish, but my clothes actually do come out cleaner (especially the whites) since using the Bible. I may add The 50 Funniest American Writers to the other corner to completely overcome ring-around-the-collar. Score:

Review:
When KafKa died, this novel, on which he had already stopped working for a few years, was left unfinished.  It actually ends in mid-sentence!

The reader is told nothing of the internal thoughts of the protagonists, of their real motivations and objectives. There is no resolution to the multiple questions that arise from the plot.  In fact, as the same events are often reported very differently by various characters, the reader is led to ponder about the relativity of truth.

Though challenging in its substance, this novel is easy to grasp and fully enjoyable.

It is strongly recommended to all who enjoy modernity.

Review:
I love the idea of this book, and some of the activities are perfectly age appropriate and I enjoy doing.  Others are so off-base I can hardly believe it.  For example:  When your baby is about 10 1/2 months old, you are supposed to put 3 objects in front of her, tell her the names of them, try to get the baby to say the object's name, and then ask for one of the objects and have the baby hand it to you.  On a good day, an 18 month old should be able to do that!  At 10 1/2 months, a baby is just going to stare at you, and pick her favorite object to chew.  This game is not the least bit developmentally appropriate at all.

It also doesn't take into account that babies develop at different speeds.  According to this book, your baby should have a pretty wide range of vocabulary by age 1.  A few babies do, but most don't.  It would be nice if the book included some modified suggestions for babies who may not be up to the game suggested.

Still, my daughter is 11 months and we've had fun going through the book doing the activities that are appropriate.  I think that this is a great resource, and I do recommend purchasing it.  I just think that it could be better.

Review: Is motherhood the most important thing in a womans life? In Getting Past Perfect, this wife and mother of fives answer might surprise you. Kate Wicker addresses this question and other popular myths about motherhood in her latest book. Ive often felt as though Im missing out because we don't have children of our own. Ive also felt as though I should be closer to perfect as a caregiver, nanny, and/or teacher because Im not on the job 24/7 like parents are. Each chapter starts out with a catchy title followed by two statements: the first is a myth about motherhood referred to as an Evil Earworm, and the second is called Unvarnished Truth. The premise of the book is expressed succinctly on page 1: Evil Earworm Being a mother is the most important thing a Catholic woman can do. Unvarnished Truth Motherhood is not your highest calling. Being a daughter of God is. Wow! What a great reminder! I love children and have very much enjoyed being part of the village to help raise some of them. There have certainly been times when I have put my job/vocation of taking care of and teaching other peoples children above my role as daughter of God and wife. Even without our own kids, Ive fallen into the trap of getting wrapped up in the little people in my care to the exclusion of some of the other priorities I ought to have. My view that I should be able to reach something closer to perfection when taking care of or teaching children because Im not on call 24/7 is pretty skewed. Ive been reminded of how impossible this is numerous times over the past several years, yet part of me still believes that I should strive for perfection instead of excellence. Clearly, Kate Wicker is a kindred spirit who has struggled with similar notions regarding motherhood. Whether you are biologically and/or legally responsible for the children in your care 24/7 or for a limited period of time each weekday, the truth is youll make some mistakes. Despite your best intentions, past experiences, whatever reading you have done or on-the-job training youve completed, there will be times when youll not be as patient, pleasant, or compassionate as you are able to be. A woman can strive to do her best to be kind, gentle, and loving with children in her care, but sometimes she will fail miserably to be any one of those things. That doesnt mean she is a failure as a caregiver, nanny, or as a mother. It means shes human. Whether you have half a dozen children of your own or provide daytime childcare for one infant, your physical, emotional, intellectual, and spiritual strength and endurance will be tried. There will be precious moments and warm memories to melt your heart, and there will be others that are nothing short of exasperating and heart-wrenching. Getting Past Perfect illustrates how it is possible to be a woman grounded in prayer, lifted up in love, realistic when it comes to the importance of her vocations as wife and mother, as well as honest when taking care of little people has brought her to her knees in tears. When people tell you to enjoy every minute of motherhood, its okay to look at them like they're crazy. When you're in the middle of the grocery store with a preschooler who insists on pushing the cart, a toddler whos stripping in public, and an infant with poop oozing out one side of his diaper, you can be honest and loathe that moment of motherhood without being thought of as some ungrateful wretch who doesnt deserve children. In addition to denying the ability to be perfect, Kate Wicker reminds readers that no matter how much we love the children God has placed in our arms and on our hearts, He loves them infinitely more. When we are facing circumstances outside of our control, the best thing we can do is offer the precious lives in our care for a time back to the Lord God who created them. Raising children doesnt have to be a blessing or a cross that you bear on your own. You can share it with your husband, family, friends, and community. Most importantly, you can share the responsibility of saying and doing whats best with God. I highly recommend Getting Past Perfect: How to Find Joy and Grace in the Messiness of Motherhood (A Catholicmom. Com Book). I was interested in reading it the moment I heard Kate Wicker was coming out with another book. I was slated to review it in the fall, but I couldn't handle reading it at that time when so much was happening that made our childless marriage so hard to deal with. I also suggest checking out Kate Wickers first book entitled Weightless: Making Peace With Your Body. I enjoyed it and knew I would like the authors next book as much if not more. I feel as though I could write a companion book that is for nannies and childcare providers. Score:

Review:
Update 2017-08-15 Additional Testing

I did some additional testing after the tear down which revealed the USB pass thru on the first port and the valid USB 3.0 hub chip.  I was very curious at this point as there was no reason that this should not perform at least as well as other devices have plugged into the same 19 pin header.  Additional testing shows that indeed, this device does perform above USB 2.0 speeds for the USB ports.  However, the card reader is definitely USB 2.0 and the USB-C port labelled as USB 3.1 is truly a USB 3.0 port with the USB C form factor.

The issue was an add in USB 3.0 PCIe card that I had bought to add an extra 19-pin header for this device.  In my testing however, I had directly connected the device to the motherboard 19pin, so I did not suspect this PCIe card as being the problem.  However, it seems it was creating some angst on my PCIe bus which resulted in decreased performance of even my onboard USB.  Removing that USB card allowed this USB hub to perform inline with expectations.

I have added a star, though I still see the false advertising as unforgivable given that the card reader is USB 2.0.

Update 2017-08-11 After Mfg Comment

After the comments by the mfg, I did further investigation.  I have attached photos to support that investigation.  This investigation verified my assertion that the card reader portion of this device is __not__ USB 3.0 but rather is a USB 2.0 device.  The card reader is supported by the Ascore AU6477DL, a USB 2.0 card reader chip, it is not capable of reading moder SD Cards at full speed.

On the other hand, the USB ports seem to be in order, with the exception of the port labelled USB3.1, which is a USB C 3.0 port.  The USB C connector does not make the port USB 3.1.  The first USB 3.0 port is a direct pass thru from the 19 pin header, and should have no issues.  I will do some additional testing to see if this proves true.  The other USB ports including the USB-C port are connected to an internal USB 3.0 Hub supported by a VIA VL813, a legitimate USB 3.0 hub chip.  There is no explanation for the low performance that I saw.  I will do additional testing.

Original Review

I wanted to like this.  I needed it to work well, it is a flop.  I have always seen Kingwin as an excellent brand, albeit a bit overpriced.  At this point I didn't care.  I am desperate for a high quality high performance card reader insert.  This is not it.

Immediately my hopes were shattered after examining it out of the box. There were 3 connectors, a 19pin for the USB3.0 and USBc ports.  A Sata connector for the eSata port and a USB2.0 header for the card reader.  Yes a USB2 header connector for the card reader ports meaning that performance of the card reader maxes out at USB 2.0 speeds 480 Mbps or 60 MB/s.  I thought hmph.. well ok at least I will go from 2 front facing USB3.0 to 3 + a USB C style USB 3 port.  So I installed anyhow and booted up and started to benchmark some SD cards, the main reason I need the card reader.  I knew that using the card reader was pointless so I stuck with my Saitec USB3 reader and started running tests.  The Saitec plugged into one of the previous 2 USB 3.0 ports, plugged into the same 19 pin motherboard header has no problem sustaining 90MB/s reads and writes on quality SD cards.  So I connected the Saitec and ran a benchmark on what should have been a very fast card, and it capped around 40MB/s.  I tried three other cards, with the same results.  I tried the same cards in a HooToo USB C reader plugged into the USB C port and again the same results.

I purchased a PCIe card with a 19pin header to work with this.  Unfortunately my computer doesn't seem willing to take another PCIe card, but if you need one this looks like a good option.
http://amzn.to/2wIEzsd

I do recommend this Saitec USB 3.0 reader though, it has worked very well for all but the most cutting edge SD cards.
http://amzn.to/2vjHXvE

Conclusion.  The  card reader will only connect to a USB 2.0 header.  The USB 3.0 ports seem to be managed by a USB 2.0 hub.  All in all this was a waste.  I'll have to try again.

Review:
People face situations that cause worry and anxiety almost daily and some of these can lead to disabling fear.  Author Maria Furlough has chosen to write about her own experiences with fear and the ways that she has learned to deal with it and she also shares the fear-filled situations of other people in her new book "Breaking the Fear Cycle". Two of the methods she has found successful to find peace for her anxious heart are going to God in prayer and seeking guidance through His Word. This book is filled with Bible passages that have strenghtened her and guided her in her own journey with fear and she has added an appendix titled In Case of an Emergency that allows you to easily find an applicable verse to ease any fears you may face.  There are also Questions for Reflection at the end of each of the eleven chapters and a Leader's Guide to use if a group study is desired. Maria Furlough has used her personal experiences to help others and I believe that this book is so very relevant to today's society. Breaking the Fear Cycle is a wonderful resource!

Review:
Plot Summary:  Anita is being worked to the bone raising corpses, and she's still dodging the attentions of Jean-Claude, the master vampire of the city.  When Anita's police consultation work interrupts the animator business, her boss hires a powerful, fresh-faced, ignorant kid to pick up the slack.  He's a wanna-be vampire slayer, and Anita takes him under her wing, like a puppy who needs protecting.  A bunch of powerful new vampires show up, all eager to take Jean-Claude down, and since Anita is one of the few humans who knows his identity, she becomes everyone's favorite target.

There actually wasn't much plot to this one.  Bad vampires want to take control away from Jean-Claude, and Anita gets caught in the middle.  That pretty much sums it up.  The plot may be shallow, but the action was so hot that my eyeballs feel dry from reading it nonstop.  I just couldn't read it fast enough during those life or death scenes; I must have flown through the pages at lightening speed.  I'm not sure how this novel would stand up to repeated readings, but it's a fantastic fantasy thriller the first time around.

There was some progress made between Anita and Jean-Claude.  I'm not sure where this twisted relationship is headed, but it's far from dull.  I happened to be in the library today, and a lady was sitting on the floor directly in front of the shelf that holds all of Ms. Hamilton's books.  She told me these were the best vampire books ever, and I could tell that she's read them all, but she couldn't stop ogling them.  When I meet fans like this, or maybe I should call them fanatics, I'm inclined to think their fascination stems from Jean-Claude rather than Anita.  I suppose time will tell as I get deeper into this series.  For myself, I read these because Anita is such a tough little cookie.

Review:
Guidebooks play several different roles -- first in planning a trip, second in helping the reader to anticipate the pleasure of a trip and third and most important during the trip itself.

This book is probably good for someone planning a whirlwind visit to California taking in the top sites. It won't do so well for someone planning a more leisurely look at one particular region.

As I reviewed this book, I was in the process of planning a trip to Santa Barbara and the coast up to Big Sur. This book is entirely inadequate for that. It doesn't mention at all places like Cambria of Ojai.

In most towns, even major destinations like Santa Monica, it only lists two or three hotels and restaurants. A visitor to one of the great National Parks would definitely need to supplement this with a more detailed guide. If you want to visit the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, there is one paragraph telling you it's pretty good and has some good stuff - but no detail. Same with the Getty Museum and Mansion.

Having said that, California is a big place with lots to see and do and this book gives a pretty decent overview of the high points.

Review:
Three Days to Never is a spy thriller mixing science, the supernatural and international intrigue in the style of Tim Powers' earlier Declare. While the two books share some similarities I did like Declare better for its grander scale and its tendency to grow on you. Three Days to Never has different strengths. It is more focused and provides a remarkably original treatment of time travel. The definitive time travel story after H G Wells' Time Machine was and remains Isaac Asimov's The End of Eternity (published in 1955). Many science fiction writers have dealt with the inherent paradoxes of time travel including the "killing your own grandfather" paradox. Many have paid lip service to Isaac Asimov, some have ignored his fascinating original assertion about the inertia of history, but none has come even close to surpassing him. Here Tim Powers gives us the most original and though-provoking treatment of time travel since Asimov, who I am quite certain he has read and internalized. As expected his blend of science and the supernatural has a completely different flavor from hard science fiction and this particular book is sometimes disorienting (no doubt like being blind but being able to see through the eyes of people nearby, like one of the characters) but it is also smart and provocative.

Powers writes with erudition. There are many references to Shakespeare's Tempest and other literary landmarks. A more subtle touch is a character with the name Lepidopt. Lepidoptera is the order of insects that includes butterflies and no doubt the allusion is to the "butterfly effect", which would be pertinent to the story. I did think that involving Einstein was somewhat unnecessary, but on balance there seems no other way to set up the story in quite the same terms. The role of Charlie Chaplin, though, is a stretch.

I first thought the ending, while quite dizzying (like the characters' use of double astral projections), was a little anti-climactic. On reflection I think Powers has got it right and proves himself a very thoughtful writer. The alternatives would inevitably either be inconsistent, or worse, hyped-up versions of exactly the same denouement. This book is a ground-breaking contribution to time travel fiction.

Review:
Oh Lord, how I've come to love my sunflower spouts!!!  They are so delicious, and good for you.  I had a big pile of them on grilled hamburgers last night!  Awesome!

These seeds seem to be very high quality.  I've tried some other seeds with middling to poor results.  But these always turn out great.  I love them, and just ordered a big batch of new seeds.

Here's how I grow them.  I bought two plastic shoe boxes from the dollar store, drilled holes in bottom of both for drainage.  I cut a piece of plastic craft/embroidery mesh to fit the bottoms of both boxes.  I put a half cup of seeds in a mason jar, and soak over night.  Then I drain and rinse twice a day for 3-4 more days.  At this point, there is a half inch white shoot coming out of most the seeds.  Then, dump into one shoebox on top of the mesh piece, spread evenly.  The mesh will provide a foothold for the roots.  Place the second box ON TOP of the newly sprouting seeds.  Put a good amount of weight in the top box.  A few cans of corn, a brick, etc.  This will help the sprouts take root, plus build up some strength.  In addition, it will make the sprouts all grow to about the same height, which looks nice and is easier to cut.  After a few days under the weight, the sprouts are greening up and pushing upward, then remove the top box and let them grow a few more days.  During this entire process you should be rinsing and draining your sprouts two to three times daily.  Leaving the top box in place, I run water between the two boxes, which helps the sprouts from moving too much, helping them take root. As your sprouts feel more secure, run you fingers over the tops, under running water to help remove the black shells.  A few stubborn shells will need to be picked off.  You don't want to eat the black shell, or the root portion.  When ready, slice near the bottom.  An advantage of the plastic mesh mat is that you can lift it out of the box to make slicing at the base of the sprouts easier.  I usually cut what I need and keep rinsing to keep them fresh.  But if you cut them all off, they keep pretty well in a plastic bag in the fridge.

And if you were REALLY SMART, about half way thru this, you'd have started a second batch, that can go under the box with the other sprouts!  Keep it going!  You won't want to be without these sprouts in your kitchen.

Review:

But, this is nothing for a metaphysical detective. Then, not to mention that she can sense that there is something a foot, with her wedding guests, something involving black magic, possibly even necromancy. This should be an easy enough case for her to figure out...as long as she can find out where the hell her fiance is.

'She could see it all crumbling now, the faint outlines of the life she's planned with Donovan, disintegrating. Her aunts were right. Necromancers were always alone, largely because they were always trying to kill each other. There was no one to trust. Innocents got caught in the cross-fire. And Riga had once joked the necromancer on necromancer violence kept the population down.'

Review:
This toggle switch is Leviton model No. 1461. Unlike some single-pole switches, this one comes with a grounding screw.

When it is off (down position), the toggle glows orange. When it is on (up position), the glow is off. The point is to make it easy to find in the dark. This is the opposite of a pilot light switch - those glow when on, and not when off.

The orange glow looks very dim in the daytime but it's just bright enough to easily be seen in the dark. The toggle is clear and transparent. A frosted or more opaque toggle (as some others are) would make the light more even and diffuse - it's a little bit 'industrial-looking' to use in a bedroom, but it's perfect for a workshop or basement.

Review:
Very thin metal.  Cheap-looking.  I bought and installed a pair of these.  I had difficulty installing because the mounting nuts are round, threaded only partway through. Unless the bolts projecting outward from the box's mounting plate protrude exactly the right length through the base, those mounting nuts will either (a) not tighten far enough to secure the unit or (2) will provide insufficient end threads on which to screw the nuts.  My electrical box (like many) is recessed a bit from the cedar siding, more on one side than the other.  I found in some cases, the mounting screws were not long enough to reach through the lamp base, while in other cases they were too long.  I bought several different lengths of screws to find ones that would work.  Best solution, however, was to use brass nuts with through threads so that longer screws can run all the way through the nuts and exact lengths do not matter so much.

Review:
To me it doesn't taste as sweet as real sugar, but that's fine since I don't like too much sweetness anyway.  But it seems to me that 2 xylitol cubes are equivalent to the taste of 1 sugar cube.  I figured out how to make sugar cubes out of these!  Just wet the xylitol a bit to make it clump and mix it (only about 2 or 3 teaspoons of water per cup of xylitol) take a silicone mini ice-cube tray and pack the moist xylitol into the cubes as tightly as possible.  Then just leave it to dry for about 10-12 hours (maybe more in a humid climate).  Wallah!  when you twist the tray out will come sugar cubes!

At first I made the mistake of trying to make sugar cubes with this product the same way I do with real sugar.  What a waste that was.  It ended up turning into a weird clear gel-like substance in the oven.  But it turns out it's even easier to make cubes with this stuff than with real sugar because you don't even need an oven!  Just laying them to dry overnight makes nice hard cubes that dissolve easily in tea and coffee.

Review:
I first read The Man in the High Castle years ago, along with most of Philip K. Dick's other novels and stories. I loved it then, but the years were unkind to my recollection of it, so I wanted to reread it before embarking on the new TV show. Rather than just read it casually, my wife and I decided to read it together, chapter by chapter, and discuss what we had read. So each week, we read, and on Sunday, we re-read out loud the entire chapter, then discussed. This activity opened the secrets of this novel up in ways that I couldn't have imagined. I believe I'll read it every year going forward. Strong prose isn't usually attributed to 'science fiction', but this is extremely well written. Each section is written in a style mimicking the way the characters might talk, whether it be a broken type of English, or otherwise. The characters are multi-dimensional... and you can almost take that literally. The story speaks on authenticity, the human experience's possible meaninglessness, and 'who the hell cares if it's meaningless anyway'. The acknowledgement of nothingness as goal. The high castle might just be a stucco job in Glendale, maybe it's your house. Look at the things you have stacked up everywhere, what do they really mean to  you, and why. Ubik.

I wholeheartedly recommend this novel and this writer. Hilarious. Thought provoking. Mind boggling. Sometimes downright insane. Psychedelic. Goofy. You've probably loved a movie that this writer inspired. But be warned. Philip K. Dick's works, most that I've read, have a surface, and one can usually glean the surface, enjoy, and move on. Don't be that someone. Dig a little deeper. You won't regret it. Of course, all this began with the TV show. Now I'm terrified to watch it. Can anyone guide me?

Review:
Nine months ago, one of these showed up by the sink in the kitchen at my office, which is shared by around 50 people. I have been intrigued as I watched it reliably deliver a "dab" of diswhashing soap countless times a day. My first impression was "somebody's throwing money away at work". The design was attractive, and as I used it, I noticed it did not leak. Best of all, it was the perfect way to get soap on very dirty or greasy hands without getting grease or dirt on the soap container.

Finally, I was at home last week, trying to wipe the dripped soap from the regular dispenser off our counter, and said, "wait a minute, I know a better way," and placed an order. Because this thing had held up so well in our office, I had no trepidation about paying the somewhat hefty price. That said, when this arrived, my wife and I had it up and running in five minutes, although I will concede the instructions are "succinct". I can see how the priming "scrap of paper" could have been missed, but it also seems to be clear in the rest of the packaging what to do.

This is an attractive and very functional tool and is elegant in design and manufacture. Simplehuman obviously gives great thought to the design and manufacture of their products, and as my wife looked through their catalog, I am reconciled that this will turn out to be more expensive than the purchase price (as my wife identifies other needs).

I believe we will end up saving significant money by not wasting nearly as much dishwashing soap. I find the amount dispensed entirely adequate to cleaning greasy pots and pans, so I'm sure it's fine for ordinary dishes too. I will be washing more dishes by hand now that my wife has noticed the Simplehuman dish draining racks in their catalog.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

Review:
Susan Matthews, with her books about Inquisitor Andrej Koscuisko, has done that rarest of things: she has created a character completely unlike any other in contemporary science fiction. Nor do her secondary characters necessarily suffer in comparison, as everyone you meet in these novels has real depth and makes sense as a human being. Matthews also does something else I like, i.e. she never patronizes her readers. This series is compelling, intelligent, and utterly original.

The Jurisdiction universe is a vicious, unforgiving place to live, a place where torture is routine and the interplanetary government continues with its slow-motion campaign of genocide against the Nurail. Andrej, in spite of his authoritarian upbringing, has finally come to the realization that he doesn't have to play along with the system any longer. I expect to see him do real damage to Jurisdiction in future books, though we don't quite get to that here. I hope the next book comes out before too much time elapses....

The only criticism I have of the book is the method used to decide what happens with the Jurisdiction hierarchy now that the First Secretary is dead. There is just no way that the Judges (not to mention the various bureaucracies attached to the Judges) would allow the small group of Bench Specialists to decide their fate, no matter how smart and supposedly disinterested said Specialists may be. Powerful people don't become or remain powerful by handing over their destinies to people they can't control. And this universe is all about control, control, control. Fierce politicking and numerous assassinations, I could have believed.

That said, this book and this series are still much better than 95% of the science fiction out there right now. You won't regret adding this novel to your collection.

Review:
Wow! What a ride! There are so many twists and turns in this book that I feel like I've been on a wild roller coaster ride. Lady Maybe is a book filled with bad choices, betrayal, and treachery. It clearly shows the consequences of these. However, there is also forgiveness and love. The book opens with Lady Marianna Mayfield getting ready to leave Bath for a place unknown to her. Her husband, Sir John, doesn't want anyone to know where they are going, so hopefully her lover, Anthony Fontaine, will not follow. Lady Mayfield's former companion, Hannah Rogers, returns just that day to collect some funds due her (she had left without word several months earlier). Lady Mayfield talks Hannah into traveling with them. Almost to their destination, there is a terrible storm and their coach goes over a cliff into the river. Only two people are saved and both are "insensible" for a period of time. They are near enough to Sir John's home to be taken there, where we meet kind Dr. Parrish, his snooty wife, their son Edgar, and the housekeeper, dear Mrs. Turrill (one of my favorite characters).  A little later, add a baby, his depressed wet nurse, and a suspicious solicitor to the mix.
And, is the Lady Mayfield that was saved, the real Lady Mayfield? What will happen if she is not?
I read LADY MAYBE all in one day, finishing about midnight. I was tired and ready to sleep but my mine was so full of the happenings in this book (especially the very satisfying ending) my mind wouldn't settle down for quite awhile. I woke this morning again with my head full of this book. Readers of Regency romance with some suspense will adore LADY MAYBE. i highly recommend it.

Review:
When the only life Ada Wentworth ever knew was ripped away from her along with her only love she leaves Boston for the small town of Hickory Ridge to accept a job as Lillian Caldwell's Companion. She expected to tend to Lillian's needs but she never expected to fall in love with Lillian's nephew Wyatt Caldwell. Wyatt loves Ada with a fierceness he never expected but can Ada forget past hurts and learn to trust again?

Wyatt always dreamed of going back to his home in Texas to take back the ranch land that was stolen from his family. It's something that has kept him driven but will he give up that dream and stay in Hickory Ridge for Ada?

With Ada's uncertainty and Racial tensions running rampant in Hickory Ridge, Ada feels she should give up her dream of owning a hat shop and go back to Boston. Can she let the only man she's ever truly loved go or will she open her heart to love him Beyond All Measure?

Dorothy Love has such a way of spinning a story that you get completely lost in the pages. She adds just enough elements of Faith without overrunning the pages with it. I completely fell in love with the characters and the town of Hickory Ridge. 5 Stars and a MUST read!

Review:
CORRUPT BY PENELOPE DOUGLAS

So , does this story really need another review? Probably not. I wasn't going to review only because there are so many but the writing has stayed with me. The story was good but the writing pulling in the reader is better. How can this be?

Corrupt has all the "right " characteristics to pull in the would be reader to read this story... intriguing cover, good ratings, many reviews, fantastic author. Readers know that when Penelope writes a Newish Adult read they will get exactly what they want which includes some smoking hot scenes. The story is filled with an intricate web of assumptions and deceit. The story flows well and no doubt about it , is a page turner. I normally do not care about believability when I read, it's fiction however there were a couple character points I couldn't get past. Most young people at 16 are dumb to a point mix in the fact that Erika is sheltered there are some not so great decisions that would be made. However knowing that and buying into her character development just didn't seem realistic. I mean the empowerment and growth she experiences within the course of 12 hours...meehhhhh is a bit too hard to believe for me. Micheal's "transformation" felt the same way but it wasn't as extreme. Evolving/growing over time I get and that was fine but that one night...just felt off.

One night.... decided so much. I loved this intricate web of deceit. Was it enough to cause such extensive damage? Eventually yes, the author does a fantastic job incorporating the reader in the characters mindset. The whole premise of such young people going through all this and or reacting , playing the way they do in Penelope's stories is one reason why I love her stories. This is not the sticking point with me however the specific character actions and or growth were.

This is still a 4-4.5 star read meaning I really liked it, I just didn't love it. I did however love the freaking m/f/m good lord almighty above... EXPLOSION ...POOF...DONE. Even though in the back of my mind i thought they were going to fall over. OH and I was like wait, there was a bench there the whole time?

Penelope Douglas is one of my fave authors, yeah I love her writing/stories but I love her no nonsensical practicality. She is genuine and real , I don't see ego. Regardless of what she writes, I will always 1 click and always read.

Review:
I pretty much swore off this series after the last book and wasn't even anticipating Lover Reborn.  But when I saw it sitting on the library shelf I gave in to the BDB pull despite knowing I would likely be disappointed.  Tohr was, after all, one of my favorites.  And ultimately I was not surprised that it contained Ward's latest annoying habit - dedicating half a book to a past couple/character.  UGH.  If John and Xhex were even a remotely believable mated couple than MAYBE it wouldn't be so brain-numbing to read about their melodrama.  However, this was a pairing that never felt genuine in the first place and enforcing unnecessary complications on them in order to pad another's story was annoying, horribly boring and just plain badly done.  And only cemented that they were never a solid pairing.  Very unfortunate decision on Ward's part, yet again.  A lot of her recent books have contained the same writing errors in judgement that can be found here, as well.  The Take Two of Xhex and John aside, Lover Reborn had too great a uniformity between all the characters in the way they speak, think and interact.  Apparently, the BDB lingo extends to even shellans and secondary characters.  Well, excluding the Chosen.  Verily verily.  And what was up with the questions without question marks.  Sorry Ward but you are not good enough to rewrite what proper punctuation is.  And the sudden unimportance of the Lessening Society is strange and doesn't seem to fit with the entire premise of the BDB world.  Just not buying it.

And though I'm liking Layla for the first time and am intrigued by the direction her story is taking, I do not like the 'let's get pregnant so we have somebody to love' part.  AHH.  Why, oh why?  I do like Quinn and Blay.  Too bad they can't just have an HEA.  But even though the next book might be about them...Ward will screw it up.  Evidence of this is everywhere.  It seems she can't just write a tight, intense and sensible story anymore.

And Tohr?  Well...it could have been worse.  But would have been better if the BDB mansion hadn't already descended to a bad soap opera.  He deserved more.  And more to the point - Autumn/No'one deserved more.  She deserved a true mate.  A bonding scent, possessive, loving Mate.  She got the short straw though and doesn't that seem to make her a perpetuating tragedy?

Now the Band of Bastards is working for me.  But this could just because the BDB has stalled, gotten stale and needs a knew cast of reliable characters.  Maybe, just maybe, focusing outside the BDB mansion will help Ward refocus her writing and storytelling.  Here's hoping....though I sense a Tohr and Autumn Take Two in the future.  Sigh.

Review:
I will begin by writing that my knowledge of French history is not as strong as my knowledge of English history so I was excited to explore something new. I knew bits and pieces about Louis  XIV and his reign but not much about Athenais, the Shadow Queen as she was known. The title of this book is a bit of a misnomer as it is more about Athenais maidservant, Claudette than about Athenais herself. So if you are looking for a novel about the court of Louis XIV and the machinations of his mistress you will not be fully satisfied with this tale for while it does show some of that it is more focused on Claudette and the theatre life of the times.

I found the book rather fascinating despite the fact that I didn't exactly get what I was promised by the title. I'm fascinated by the theatre and to read about the greats of this time - Moliere, Racine and Corneille - kept me turning the pages. It gave full bodied life to what had before been names on a page to me. The mores of the time were also quite interesting and to read about the battles between the church, the king and the theatre - fascinating. There was an author's note in the back which explained more about the times. I always appreciate such an addition although I'm one to delve into further research anyway.

Neither of the two protagonists is entirely likable but Claudette comes out ahead in that many of her decisions were almost forced upon her by the need to care for her family and societal pressures of the times in which she lived. Athenais has come down through history with many a question swirling about her and this novel does nothing to brighten that reputation.

The novel reads quickly and delves into the backgrounds of Claudette's parents and brother. Both the gritty side of life in Paris and the court life are written well. The ending was somewhat of a disappoint and a little confusing and abrupt. After so much attention to Claudette's life it seemed to just end with a whimper.

3.5

*I received a free copy for my honest review

Review:
I have purchased several adult coloring books, but "Exquisite Flowers: Color. Dream. Create" is my favorite so far and the one that actually got me coloring for a prolonged period of time.  This book taught me that coloring can indeed be a relaxing, meditative experience - now I get what all the excitement is about.

There are three things that really make this book great:
1. The designs are attractive with good size areas to color.
2. Since the background is already "colored" - it takes away the monotony of coloring a large area and you get to color the fun stuff! (and you're finished quicker too)
3. The paper quality is excellent - very thick and blank on the reverse side; I have experienced no bleed through and I have tried markers, pencils and even water color pencils.

In the photo below I have used various kinds of coloring tools and listed them so you can see how they work on this book.

Great quality - great pictures - great fun!  Definitely recommend.

Update:  the last thing I colored was the center flower and I used alcohol markers; while these produced my favorite results, there was some bleed through to the back.  If you are using alcohol markers like Spectrum Noir or Copic, I would use something between the pages, perhaps a craft sheet or waxed paper.

Review:
The Night Circus had points that dragged a bit for me, where I wished for more action and for events to unfold, but despite its slow motion, the book paints a gorgeous black and white picture of a magical traveling circus that you wish could be real. As the tents and acts are described, your mind wanders, trying to picture each little detail, and possibly how it could be accomplished sans magic, and before you know it you've read an entire page without really remembering any of the details and have to go back. I loved the wonder of the whole circus, and even though the reader knows that its really magic there, the circus attendees don't, and it leaves you trying to picture it the way the circus-goers view it. Really, what does happen when magic is introduced to an audience that doesn't believe it exists? How do they wrap their minds around it, and how do the performers hide the magic in plain sight? It was definitely a good read

Review:
A different take of the iconic "Pretty Woman" storyline, "A Kept Woman" is the story of business tycoon and billionaire Derek Davenport and Arianne, an out-of-work children's books illustrator whom Derek hired as a once-a-week sexual companion.

It was all business in the beginning, but both Arianne and Derek felt stirrings of love which both tried very hard to avoid and stop to no avail.

Since this is romantic erotica, a happy ending is a given. What makes this story standout is the matter-of-fact, very contemporary and very believable attitude of the hero and heroine. The dialogue is also great, which by the way is the reason why readers stay with the book until the end. Both Arianne and Derek are not predictible as protagonists. They always have a surprise up their sleeves until the end.

This is definitely an erotica story and the sex scenes sizzles. But, since it was all written in context, it is not salacious.

Review:
This book covers two diets; the anti-inflammation diet and the Dash diet. It is a well written book
with a lot of valuable information.

Chronic inflammation can cause a lot of diseases. The diet is not intended for weight loss. It is
meant to provide meals made from foods meant to prevent swelling. The list of foods allowed
includes fish, olive oil, kelp, blueberries, green leafy vegetables, sweet potatoes, garlic, ginger,
turmeric, and green tea.

If on this diet alcohol should be avoided as well as refined sugar, trans fats, dairy, white flour
and things made with it, and processed foods.

Tips include eating fresh food, watch calories and carbohydrates, watch fats, get enough
protein, fiber and nutrients. Learn to cook differently. Stir fry instead of deep frying, bake and
poach or grill your food. The recipes included are good, the instructions are clear and the
preparation appears easy enough. The recipes are well organized and plentiful.

The Dash Diet is meant to lower blood pressure. A lifestyle change is needed to control
hypertension. High blood pressure can cause heart disease, kidney failure, stroke and
other conditions. The Dash Diet is not intended for weight loss but can definitely be used
to lose weight. This diet recommends a certain number of different kinds of foods on a
weekly basis. The recipes are good, the instructions seem clear, and the preparation
seems easy enough. Again the recipes are well organized.

I received this book free in exchange for my honest review.

Review:
This is the Fourth installment of the Cold Fury and in my opinion, the best one yet.

Ryker Evans is a new single father and struggling to figure out how to take care of two very small, very adorable daughters; Ruby and Violet make Ryker's world turn. And I've got to say it was so much fun reading how very young, small females can turn even the biggest, baddest man into jello.
Not only does Ryker have to worry about his girls, but he's also the replacement goalie. Yeah, his stats are off the charts but when you're considered an "old man" in a field full of younger guys, he has to work harder, be stronger and keep his s***e together.
Too bad the new GM of the Fury is making him take his eye off the goal.

Gray Brannon has always been into hockey. She's got the medals to prove it too.
When her Dad steps down from the General Manager position; it only makes sense that he names Gray as his successor.
She's got a whole lot of the girl thing going on and she's bad-ass enough for the job too.
But the real work will be proving it to not only the rest of the suits, but also to the team.

Misgivings, prejudice and all around stubbornness color her rise as GM of the Cold Fury. But she's got the time and patience to try and turn everyone around. The only one that seems to be behind her is Ryker.
He's tall, dark and sexier than any one man should be. And he puts her in a very shaky position.

Trying to keep their budding relationship on the down-low and Ryker's ex from trying to worm her way back into his life has the couple dealing with more than just Hockey.
But danger from an unexpected source has Ryker rethinking everything.

Ryker is one bad ass Daddy.

Sawyer Bennett out wrote herself when she made Ryker. He's everything every woman in the world wants. Including me.
Reviewed for FMRBookgrind

Review:
To those who are put off by Ziglar's religious tone to this book in their reviews, even Ziglar states that he knows some people might be put off by it, and 20+ years ago he was not a real believer in God or anything else. He just wanted to make money. He states the change came over time.

I am not Christian, but I am spiritual. Yet I was not offended or bothered by his religious overtones. After all, he is just stating openly what he calls the passion to his success. How his life and the lessons in his life changed when he did take God into his heart and follow God's path. I feel no reason for me to be closed minded to his writing as I truly respect the man and the good he has done. Maybe, just maybe I can be even more open minded to see if his path can also be my path.

I think an important point in the book for me was when he stated all the big important people that helped to form this country (Washington, Lincoln, Benjamin Franklin, Thomas Jefferson...) and how these people and our country were built on religious standards and helped to create these great people. But as education is taught less and less from religious and moral influence (for 200 years the alphabet was taught with each letter  referencing a biblical verse and moral standard) the country has produced less and less great leaders that compare to our founding fathers. So maybe Zig has a point about incorporating a better than good life with some religious/spiritual overtones.

Finally something that really stands out for me is realizing how I and so many others who are famous (no, I am not famous) would probably change their actions if they started looking at how they are moral role-models to so many young kids and they are helping to shape the future due to their actions. I know for me I am beginning to rethink what I do and how I do it and how I might be able to help shape the future leaders with my calling.

Well, just my two cents.

Review:
I replaced my sink, disposal and faucet all at the same time.  I swapped out an old ceramic sink with a stainless steel and my badger 1 disposal with this one.  Even with sink types considered, since ceramic sinks usually dampen sound better than SS, this disposal is quiter than the old junky, defective badger 1.  I've had no problem with jams, or power of this disposal.  It's handled everything we've dumped in it without issue.  The EZ Mount system is very easy to install and since I put this on a stainless steel sink I didn't need plumber's putty.  The rubber gasket was all that was needed.

The one thing I do want to mention is that this disposal does come with a 3 prong plug, so if your previous disposal is direct wired, you will either need to wire this up to the existing wire by removing the plug or by dropping an outlet in the wall under the sink.  I opted to install an outlet.  I cut the hole, installed a post work wire box and wired a ground circuit outlet in.  Not that any of that has anything to do with the review, just gloating I guess.  Anyway, fantasitc product, and hoping it will stand the test of time as others are saying it does.

Review:

He was a little disappointed that this was the last one of the series, but he thought it ended "extremely excellently".  I read several of these books myself and found them well written and very imaginative. I only hope the author starts a new series soon, with another diverse string of equally quirky and endearing characters.

Review:

Hunter was the embodiment of several of my military buddies and their familial bond and sense of duty and honor.  He is fully committed to serving his country but still open to what life has to offer.  He began Operation Daddy with e intention of seeing to his brother and friend's last wishes were realized.

Linnea reminds me of my mom.  She is a strong, independent and courageous woman.  Linnea didn't break when the life supercharged with her mom military husband ended.  She processed her grief and moved on to raise her beautiful baby girl and in the process met her forever love.

I loved this book immensely and see a new depth in the writing one of my favorite author's of military stories.  Well done!!!

Review:
This book was a big, fat paradox, both incredibly sweet and unbelievably sexy at the same time. Alfie had been incredibly sheltered and isolated because of her flighty artistic mother who had her out of wedlock. (This is 2014, right?) Her grandfather who is the Svengali of the book, is a throwback to the 1920's. I don't know, maybe it's different in New Zealand, but he was a MAJOR tool in this American girl's honest opinion. Anyway, back to the paradox, Alfie couldn't have been any greener if she had been raised by nuns. Despite the fact that she works with livestock and is well aware of what goes where. She has been browbeaten so much and for so long by Herr Craftsman, that her sexual identity is zilch. Not only that but he has arranged a marriage, without her knowledge or consent to a man who just shows up on her doorstep. So, at this point I am seriously thinking, it might be time to pull a Menedez on ol' Granpappy. But then some strange insect made me rethink the whole sitch. New Zealand is the home of the cave weta. They only live in this tiny area of the entire world. If New Zealand can breed these critters, well maybe Pops isn't such a strange Kiwi after all.

Seriously, I thought this was photoshopped or something but this a a THING. Rory, the ex-pat Kiwi, who now hails from Texas, actually saved Alfie when a cave weta fell down her shirt. For this he deserves all the sex, and land that he could ever want. Not only did he remove the weta, he put it back in the cave so that it wouldn't die in the sunlight. I love this cowboy. With all his shucks, and darlings, he was just too, too yummy. He was actually a very decent sort, who fell into instant lust with Alfie and resented the way she had been parceled out as part of a land deal. He put a lot of effort into building up her self esteem and giving her some independence. He was also a very dirty cowboy, and I'm not talking trail dust, nosireebob! He gives Alfie some hands on training in animal husbandry. *snort*

For under one hundred and fifty pages, this was a well written, quick but satisfying romance that taught me a few things, some good and some I'll have nightmares about. *ewwwww* I think the whole weta incident pretty much put the kibosh on any future trips to New Zealand, so I guess I'll have to rely on more books from Kris to satisfy my wanderlust. Nice, job, Ms. Pearson, I enjoyed the ride.

Review:
The short story, "Flirting With Death", was the first fiction Ive ever read by Ali Winters. It won't be the last.

Winters wrote an imaginative love story between two unexpected characters, a reaper and a human. Definitely not your average couple. I loved these characters and their story.

Evander never imagined what could happen just doing his job. When the story opened, I got the sense that he had grown discontented with his position. He found the job mundane. He looked forward to finishing an assignment and moving on to the next one. The job didn't thrill him until he met the girl who intrigued him. He couldn't get her out of his mind.

Piper was the pretty girl willing to settle for a guy who mistreated her. She just wanted someone in her life. She didn't think she was worthy of doing better. Never could she have imagined that a tragedy could change her life forever.

The emotions are what made this story so good. Evanders need for something more resonated with me. I understood how his job didn't fulfill him. His feelings colored how he saw all humans. And, Pipers desperation was so palpable. Evander lit a spark in her that she wanted to embrace fully. Just one inopportune moment, and she couldn't get him out of her mind.

"Flirting With Death" was simply a good, heart felt story. I hope to read more about this interesting couple. I know Ill be reading much more by Ali Winters!

Review:
Three girls grow up in a small town near the Lebanese border in Israel. We follow their lives just before they are called in to serve in the Israeli army, through a short while after.

The stories of each one jump around and it's like being allowed into a person's mind for snippets of what they go through. We're introduced to a young man who recently served in the army and can't deal with his experiences. He's found dead with a self inflicted gunshot wound to his head. We see friends who are assigned to watch the checkpoints having their throats cut by Arabs. We see a family in the neighborhood where the wife can't deal the constant shelling by the Arabs and leaves her husband one day with their kids. We see how the war affected these women who find it hard to fit into society once their service is over.

Constant fear of something that may happen can be more damaging to a soldier than certainty. It creates an always ready attitude that's hard to shake off once they're no longer serving in the army. The toughness that's believed is part of the Israeli makeup often hides a fragile and damaged soul.

Important to read.

Review:
Though Mine is the Night by Liz Curtis Higgs focuses on three female characters, in some ways it tells the tale of all women because it's patterned after the book of Ruth. The story reminded me of this unchanging truth: No matter the culture, time period, or circumstances, God sees each woman's most-cherished dreams, hears the cries of her heart, and works His plan into her life--if she will let Him.

The drama opens in Scotland circa 1746. Anne, Marjory, and Elizabeth have each experienced painful pasts and find themselves in unfamiliar circumstances. They've lost their wealth, societal position, and family members to the failed Jacobite Rebellion. As they begin new lives, they expect no special treatment and determine to accept whatever hard work and deprivation the future may require. However, God--who delights in bestowing so much more than His children could ever ask or think--fills their lives with favor, abundant joys, and unexpected love.

As I read the story, I couldn't help but think of the many times God has surprised me with His good gifts. The accompanying verse that kept running through my mind was I John 3: 20: "For God is greater than our worried hearts and knows more about us than we do ourselves."

One Caution for Gentle Readers of This Tale: I opened this book in the late afternoon, thinking I'd take a short break before getting back to work. So quickly and effortlessly did I become immersed in the story world that I didn't return to "real life" until many hours later. My advice: don't pick up this engaging read until you're prepared to loose yourself within its pages!

Review:
The Good:

The film was well-written. It did a great job covering every facet of Daniel's amazing life as covered in the Bible. Most films will focus only on the lions den but this goes in depth. I enjoyed more than the episode of, The Bible which focused on Daniel. Most adaptations of Biblical narratives will require some speculation to fill in blanks that a movie but the Bible doesn't cover and I really liked how this movie did that.  I love the idea that Daniel was so dedicated and so faithful to King Darius that he advised there was no legal loophole and that Daniel be thrown into the lion's Den quickly so as not to give fuel to the King's political enemies. That the faith and faithfulness of Daniel. I also liked the scenes of Daniel discussing Isaiah's prophecy regarding Cyrus with Cyrus. Although I doubt it happened, it did a good job communicating through film the amazing nature of Isaiah's prophecy.

The film had some solid performances including Robert Miano as Old Daniel, really embodying the role of an Old Testament prophet  and Rolf Saxon was great as Nebuchadnezzar.

The Bad:

The film featured some cheesy performances, mostly from minor characters such as the Babylonian astrologers. Of the more important players, Lance Henriksen seemed  too subdued as Cyrus.

Costuming was a problem particularly with jewelry. Because of his jewelry, one of the astrologers reminded me of a rapper. When Belshazzar gave Daniel the gold chain, it looked so obviously fake like a prop from a church play.

The one scene the direction really let down was the finger of God writing on the wall. The scene went too fast with Belshazzar demanding a solution before the finger finished. That's a moment that would have been better with people terrified and then we get the King's response.

Overall, though, this movie is good for what it is: a well written, low budeget faithful DVD adaptation of the life of Daniel. I enjoyed it.

Review:
Once again, Kathryn has caught the reader up into the world of knights and ladies.  This time, revenge for deeds done 25 years earlier, is the root of that revenge.  Bretton de Llion was the force moving across the land, him and his mercenary army, taking castle after castle.  The pattern was a familiar course to Jax de Velt, as it was the course he had traveled 25 years before. As a lad of 5, Bretton's family was destroyed when de Velt  conquered Four Crosses Cast, Bretton's home. Now, 25 years later, Bretton is taking revenge for his families death.  His goal: regain Four Crosses Castle and kill de Velt. After kidnapping Lady Allaston Eugenia Coleby de Velt, de Velt's  daughter, Bretton's goal was strengthened.  Now he had leverage in his quest, along with his army..  More than conquer and kill, Devil's Dominion is about a man hardened by life, being taught the side of life that includes loving and caring, feelings he was not familiar with during his life.  I loved the relationship between Bretton and Allaston. She was not the type to just remain quiet.  She constantly was making Bretton thinking and looking at life from a different view. The writing of this story was wonderful.  It is written such a way that you forget all else but what is happening in the book. Reading a Kathryn Le Veque book is like visiting old friends.  Although this is a stand alone book, you catch up with characters from previous books.  It is always so great to see other facets of the persons you meet previously in other Kathryn's books.

Review:
This is a neat gizmo for tracking steps and giving you a general idea of how many calories you are burning and how much activity you are getting.  A couple of years ago I had an armband by BodyMedia which has sense gone out of business.  That was a much more accurate (but expensive) tool so I came to this one with not very high expectations, but honestly, for it's price point it is very high quality, and has some pretty amazing features.

First of all, I have very tiny wrists and this has enough holes that I can get a good fit.  I also love that the digital reading is crystal clear and that I can swipe the screen of the watch and easily move from time/battery life to steps taken to calories burned to sleep mode etc.  It is very easy to set up and use and syncs easily with my iPhone.

Overall, it is very comfortable to wear and lightweight, but it does shift periodically and I get a little vibration that tells me that it's not making a full connection and I can adjust - cool feature.

Cons: I don't believe the step count is wholly accurate and this could be do to the watch slipping on my wrist periodically, but I compared this with my former armband and this is not as accurate.  It is good for a ballpark measure and it certainly is accurate enough you get a good general idea, but it is not the same as the 100-200 dollar fitness bands.

Is it worth the money - yes :).  It's much better than just a plain old pedometer, it gives you good incentive and it's easy to use.  You may want to start with this and as you progress, consider investing in a more expensive gizmo to track calories, and sleep cycles better but overall this is a great tool and I would definitely recommend it.

If you look at my pic you'll see the closing clasps - they are like little metal rods that stick up and the holes go over them.  They are very secure and I like that feature a lot.  The screen is great too very easy to read.  The battery level in my picture is after 3 & 1/2 days of continuous use - so it gets excellent battery life.  Overall this product meets my expectations.

I received a complimentary product in exchange for a thorough test and honest review.  All opinions and experiences are my own.

Review:
Indeed, this is Young at his best; in his later years he may have been less consistent than in his youth, but when he was good, boy was he good or what?
Did Teddy Wilson help make this album a masterpiece? Oh, I believe he did - since he didn't change his style very much, since he wasn't flamboyant or selfdestructive and since he lived and played consistently for very long, Mr. Wilson is not appreciated enough, but he is, I believe, the essence of swing and one of the best jazz pianist ever.
Compute for your self - his work in Benny Goodman trio and quartet is more than brilliant (check the great Carnegie Hall concert), sessions he arranged with Billie Holiday and a veritable who-is-who in jazz of the 30's (Roy Eldridge, Lester Young, Benny Goodman, Ben Webster, Johnny Hodges...)are irreplacible, whereas his work with the Pres in the 50's proves how swing was still alive and kicking at the time.

Young and Wilson share the spotlight for me on this album, but it would be a shame not to mention great bass player Gene Ramey and the great (if not the greatest) swing drummer Jo Jones who knew Pres very well from their Basie years...
"All of me" is my favorite, but "Louise" and other performances are equally beautiful...

Despite the length, Gephart's Accidental Adulthood is a smooth, entertaining and effortless read. Effortless - but far from brainless. It's a self-deprecating stream of consciousness, a celebration of Peter Pan inside every middle-aged man. It reads like a stand-up comedy skit worthy of Eric Bogosian.

- M.J. Neary, author of Saved by the Bang

The top can be taken apart and easily dishwashed. I like how the internal straw is clear so I can see if anything dark and gross is growing in there (so far, nothing!). The mouth straw piece and long straw piece can be easily cleaned with a straw brush or placed into the dishwasher.

These metal bottles are heavier than simple plastic bottles, but I love the easy to clean design (I have had bottles turn dark and gross in hard to reach items), ability to keep water cool in summer, and ability to mix and match with other items in the Funtainer line. I got this for $7 from a toy warehouse sale.

Review:
The map is a bit silly and I'm not totally sure how I feel about it - why does everything for kids have to look so stupid?  I don't disagree with the notion that Kansas is basically just a giant feedlot, but Mesa Verde is not in Northeast Colorado, and is that covered wagon in Southeast Oregon supposed to represent the Oregon trail?  Some Eskimos in North Dakota would have made for some great snark and probably would have triggered a strongly worded letter from their Governor and some free publicity - just something to think about for next time T.S. Shure, if you're reading this.

Anyway, the included stickers are kind of flimsy and cheap, but the basic idea is really a great one - you can put a sticker on the map for where grandma and grandpa live, and where all the various aunts and uncles live.  Our family happens to be scattered all over the USA so this map works perfect for that.  The stickers don't really stand out much from all the zany action happening on the map, so the overall effect is not perfect.

Overall the map works for its purpose (a map to put on the wall that can stand up to some abuse) and does provide quite a bit for kids to look at and ask questions about, for example why is there a spaceship in Alabama?  (I have no idea)

Review:
and it won't be the last.

Ockler has done a pretty amazing job with characterization. I found that Hudson embodied a teenager, with the angst, emotional turmoil, and obsessions. She wasn't the perfect friend, the best sister, or obedient daughter, but she was introspective enough to see that she was failing and managed to change her own course and mend the fences that she had broken along the way. I felt that this was done in a very believable way, since I have seen very few (none?) teenagers (humans) who have not been totally selfish at one point or another.

The plot was interesting with the tie-ins of hockey, cupcakes and ice skating, an unusual mix that worked well, not to mention romance and the possibility of the family's diner being lost.

Ockler's prose was good, with no discernible hitches.

Again, I found this to be several notches about the typical YA read and will be seeking out her other novels.

Review:
deftones came into my life in 1997 with "MOS" from the rock show, with matt pinfield that mtv so helplessly pulled from the air-what else will they do with one hour every saturday night at 11?ever since buying the cd, i have been in love with each second, never ceasing to be amazed at what the deftones have created:

1. my own summer (shove it)-10/10-sheer genius.one of my favorite songs of all time.just heavy as all get out and chino screams his brains out.brilliant song.i can't say enough.

2. lhabia-9/10-a mellower, catchier chorus than "MOS", but still driving guitar riffs throughout and an amazing track

3. mascara-8/10-a soft and emo side of the deftones displaying the amazing vocal talents of chino moreno.good track,takes a while to get into but still good.

4. around the fur-10/10-the title track-back to the heaviness of the album.chorus blows up in your face after a seemingly mellow verse-interesting mellow breakdown in the middle of the song

5. rickets-8/10-not too bad, very repetitive verse that can get on your nerves but the chorus is just ridiculous.never really got into this song.

6. be quiet and drive (far away)-10/10-i never really understood the hype around this song; that is, until i lsitened to the whole song.amazing musicianship with chino's soothing vocals throughout.no wonder this song is an instant fan favorite.

7. lotion-10/10-crazy song.chino screams "i feel sickened!" like a million times and this is definitely a song full of strange guitar distortions.great cut.also a like 5 second bass solo which is cool as crap.

8. dai the flu-8/10-not too great until the middle where it really starts to become edgy and pick up the pace.then from there,it becomes a great track.skip to about 2:00.

9. headup-10/10-chaotic verses and a chorus which sounds like it features max cavalera chanting "soulfly, flyhigh".great stuff.my personal favorite after "MOS".

10. mx-10/10-its like a musical conversation between chino and a girl who chimes in after chino sings a line of the verse.the chours features his singing in an eerie watery effect.very diverse and eclectic.

overall, the deftones will never defy the magic of "around the fur".a must have for any fan of music.

Review:
Let's me start off by saying sound quality warrants a broad range of positive and negative reviews on nearly everything from low to mid to high quality products.  You can find someone "poo pooing" all over even $5,000+ systems.  I'm not an audiophile music nut but can appreciate a good quality product for music and movies.  That's what Sonos provides.  The audio is clear and beautiful.  However, if you are able to hardwire speakers and spend a bunch, this might not be a good fit.  For me, I had limited ability to subcontract out when my house was being built so I didn't want to punch a bunch of holes in the wall and snake near-endless wires around.

Sonos gave me exactly what I was looking for with minimal wires and superior sound for the amount.  Bose technology is not as innovative as it once was and Sonos provides equal or better quality for a comparable if not cheaper price.  I currently only have the playbar and subwoofer hooked up and the ease at which I can control everything through my iPhone is remarkable. I plan on adding two Play 1s when finances allow.  I can control the volume and stream music and internet radio with no fuss.  This product deserves 4-5 stars for what it is.  I will update this review when I buy the two additional speakers to add to a more balanced sound that is closer to surround sound. The two pieces I have now are very impressive products. Kodos to Sonos.

UPDATE: 3/17/15

I didn't want to heavily edit my previous review so you can see how things have changed for me.  I downgraded the star rating to two stars but could have given it a three as well.  My dissatisfaction with Sonos is largely due to its abysmal performance at producing the proper sound through my television.  I have last year's model for Sharp with their Aquos Q+ which is a superior television in my opinion and has some of the latest technology.  My current Sonos system consists of the playbar, subwoofer, and wifi extender. I have zero complaints in regards to the system producing top-notch sound when streaming anything over my iphone.  The issues arise with the television and the playbar's random flaws, which have become very annoying.  I have done the troubleshooting to correct issues and only short term relief has been experienced.  At first, I would get shows and movies in which the sound would drop out here and there for a few seconds at a time.  Now, I have constant variations with the sound levels once the television is turned on.  Additionally, I randomly get the wonderfully horrible "robotic tone" coming from actors talking and this can only be returned to normal when I change the channel and change it back.  Maybe these things can be fixed but ask yourself this: If you just spent over $1500 on a soundbar, subwoofer, wifi extender, did the recommended troubleshooting and still had issues, would you be fed-up?  I think so.  I am about to look into ebay for recouping my invested money.  I would never buy a Sonos product again until their wifi technology is better tested and works as it should.  They are a joke if they are trying to compete in their price range when there are these many issues.
